At approximately 2:19 p.m., trading activity in Audience’s stock began increasing and
the share price began to fall sharply. The volume of shares traded on January 29 (over 840,000
shares) was in excess of ten times the volume of shares traded the previous day (approximately
77,900 shares). Beginning at the time of the first tweet, Audience’s share price fell from $12.35 per
share, to reach a low of $8.87 per share, an approximately 28% drop. At 2:22 p.m., the price drop
triggered Nasdaq’s single stock circuit breaker and trading of Audience shares was halted. That same
day, Craig bought $3,549.00 worth of Audience stock, but failed to catch the stock’s intraday low
price. He later sold these shares for a profit of approximately $9.00.

PM

And...

PM

At approximately 11:18 a.m., the volume of trading in Sarepta shares began to climb
and the company’s share price began to drop. From an intraday high of $29.30 just minutes before,
Sarepta shares reached a low of $24.50, representing a drop of approximately 16%. By 11:23 am, the
price of Sarepta stock had recovered, trading at an average price of $28.32 per share. Again, that
same day, Craig bought Sarepta shares totaling $19,537, but failed to catch the intraday low price for
the stock. He later sold these shares and made a profit of approximately $88.00.

11:18 am
BE

Here's MOST.

BE

At £255m, revenues for the 4m ending October are up 9% y/y, though down
~5% y/y (excluding PVM acquisition). This implies significant (~15%
underlying ex PVM y/y) growth in the final two months to reach consensus
revenue expectations.
In addition, with limited cost flex, given regulatory cost creep, top-line pressure
is expected to lower FY15 operating profit margins by 1.5 percentage points
vs. last year, i.e. new guidance implies 13.5% margin vs. MSe & consensus at
14.5% – this is ~10% below expectations.
Tullett will take action to reduce headcount and fixed costs in the affected
areas, which is expected to result in a reduction of ~5% in the front office
headcount in the traditional interdealer product areas. As such, assuming flat
revenues next year, cost saves should help protect profitability and deliver flat
operating margins. However, this would still imply a more meaningful greater than 15%
downgrade to consensus PBT expectations for FY16.

PM

Tullett blaming the regulators

11:19 am
BE

And Barclays ......

BE

Underlying revenues ex PVM are in decline

Tullett Prebon released its Jul-Oct 2015 IMS on 6 Nov 2015. Revenues for the period July-Oct were reported at £255m, up 9% yoy, mainly driven by strong performance at PVM. However, ex-PVM Revenues were actually down -5% yoy at constant FX reflecting weakness in most asset classes outside oil. This is very much in line with our expectations of +8% headline and -5% constant scope respectively. Revenues YTD (Jan-Oct) are £671m, up 13% yoy headline but down -3% yoy ex-PVM/constant FX. Against this however management guided down FY15 operating profit and announced a resumption in headcount cuts to try and respond, which justifies our key investment thesis in our downgrade to Underweight note on 3 Nov that the company needs to do more on costs to protect the bottom line.

Operating margin guided to decline by 1.5% yoy for 2015, to ~12.8%

Management states that against a backdrop of declining volumes in June, versus the need to increase costs for regulatory readiness and investment in new initiatives, the operating margin remains under pressure. They guide to 2015 underlying operating profit margin falling by ~1.5% yoy. This is not good news as we were forecasting roughly flat operating margin in FY15 at 14.2% from 14.3% in 2014, improving to 14.5% in 2016. All else equal, we estimate the mechanical reduction to underlying 2015 EPS caused by this lower operating margin would be ~10%.

BE

Headcount cut in front office to resume, -5% reduction planned

The announcement of a resumption of cost cutting was unexpected in this statement, so is a small positive. Management states further action is required given the declining volume environment in June, especially in Europe. They intend to reduce front office headcount by a further -5% and this will book an exceptional cost in 2015, although this and the amount of costs to be saved were not quantified.

In 2015 Tullett Prebon stated it had 1745 voice brokers, although ex PVM the core business has 1617 brokers. Therefore 5% of this would be ~80 brokers. In 2014 management stated that they reduced annual fixed costs by £40m through cutting 160 front office headcount and 50 back office headcount as well as vacating office space. So we would suggest that the benefit of cutting 80 further brokers would cause a £10-15m cost benefit in 2016, however we believe this would be largely offset by the lower margin headwind.

Volume environment remains depressed

Volumes over the summer and through to Sep/Oct remained under pressure in the OTC markets due to structural and cyclical factors. The investment banks continue to deleverage in the face of regulatory pressures and have reported weak trading activity in their FICC divisions in Q3. The sustained low interest rate environment and compressed Bond spreads in Europe have depressed trading activity in Interest rate derivatives and Fixed Income products. However, while Tullet has benefited from better activity in the Oil markets through its PVM acquisition due to movement in the oil price earlier in the year, we remain cautious on the sustainability of this volatility.

Share price performance up 15% ytd prior to IMS looks unjustified in our view

The Tullett share is up 15% ytd vs the FTSE AllShare -0.7%, however it is down -20% since August. It is currently trading at ~10x 2016E PE, which looks relatively expensive vs a historic average of ~8.5x for weak earnings momentum. We do not think this is justified given there is poor underlying growth and so reiterate Underweight.

Spin Transfer Technologies’ (STT’s) patented OST-MRAM™ technology provides significant performance and scalability improvements over current spin transfer MRAM designs which involve thermodynamic processes in the initiation of magnetic switching.

STT’s OST-MRAM™ utilizes an innovative orthogonal orientation between the polarizing magnetic vector and free magnetic vector of the memory cell
results in deterministic switching of magnetic orientation, which can be accomplished in a significantly shorter amount of time, using a much smaller current than other spin transfer approaches.

These characteristics have direct impact on write speed and power consumption, broadening the application areas and increasing the attractiveness of this memory technology.

BE

What we can add is how much the iron ore mine contributes to BHP's bottom line.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Samarco contributed US$0.4 billion in dividend in FY15 to BHPB.
Samarco is a JV and BHPB does not consolidate the accounts under IFRS. The
JV contributed US$0.396 billion in dividend to BHPB in FY15 (US$0.581 billion
in FY14) or 6% of BHPB's group dividend of US$6.6 billion (US$1.24 per
share). BHPB's share of Samarco's equity amounted to US$0.6 billion and after
accounting adjustment is included in BHPB's accounts at US$1.0 billion. On a
proportionate basis, the Samarco JV provided around 3.5% of BHPB's revenue
and EBITDA. BHPB's share of production amounted to 14.5mn (pellets) in FY15
compared to 218 million metric tons from its western Australian operations
(BHPB share). We value BHPB's 50% equity stake in Samarco at GBP0.35 per
share (US$2.8 billion) within the context of our base case price target of
GBP12.

11:37 am
BE

Prolonged outage possible. The scale of the tailings breach and accident
suggests there could be a prolonged outage even if both mines do not use the
same tailings dam. The clean-up operation will take time and funding. And
potentially, the Samarco JV will have to re-apply for its operating and
environmental licenses. Samarco may be able to claim part of this back on
insurance cover which is unclear at this time. At 30 June 2015, Samarco's
balance sheet had US$0.7 billion of gross cash and gross debt of US$4.9
billion (on 100% basis).

BE

And Deutsche.

BE

The mine represents c. 10% of
our BHP earnings and 3% of NPV. We now assume the mine is shut until FY19.
Pellet production was recently expanded to 30Mtpa at a cost of US$3.2b.
Media reports have stated that there is a significant and tragic loss of life.
Based on public images of the failure we estimate that the dam contained over
300Mt or 150Mm3 of tailings and Samarco could be down for years while the
clean-up costs may exceed US$1bn. This accident will add further pressure to
BHP's cash flow, growth and safeguarding of the progressive dividend.

11:38 am
BE

At around 18.30 GMT on Nov 5, Samarco’s largest tailings facility failed,
causing slurry to race through the open pit and down the valley into the local
village of Bento Rodrigues and into local waterways. The media is reporting
that between 15 and 17 people have died and 45 others are missing. Samarco
states in its FY14 sustainability report that it employs a management system
referred to as “Failure Modes and Effects Analysis (FMEA) system” to control
tailings dam failure risks. It could be months before Vale, BHP, State and
Federal governments complete their assessment of the incident. The clean-up,
community support, litigation and rebuilding of the tailings dam (if approved
and deemed feasible) could mean that Samarco is shut for years. The mine
employs 3,100 people and is one of the largest employers in the region.
Samarco contributed US$369m to BHP earnings in FY15 and before this
incident we estimated it would contribute US$308m in FY16. We have
assumed the mine is shut until FY19, the workforce remains employed, and
BHP’s share of the clean-up and dam rebuild costs US$500m. We have
excluded any recouping of costs from insurance at this stage.

BE

The global seaborne market is around 1.55bt p.a. Samarco is therefore around
2% of global supply. Samarco’s sales split in FY14 was 23% to Africa and the
Middle East, 22% Asia (ex China), 21% Europe 17% China, and 17% Americas.
We think prices for lump and pellet will likely increase and that there might be
wider implications for Vale’s other mines with tailings dams in the Southern
System. We note the 2014 dam failure of the privately-owned Herculano mine.

11:46 am
BE

The article describes how the author came across the data, his dealings with his source
and his interactions with Optimal Payments. He comments on the sensitivity, amount
and age of the data, how such data can potentially be used on the "dark web" and the
risks to enterprises generally. The article provides many positive disclosures for Optimal
Payments:

BE

• The article indicates that data is related to attacks from 2009 and 2010. Optimal
Payments previously stated that forensic audits indicated that the NETELLER data
breach contained no evidence to suggest that the breach was material and, to the best
of the company’s knowledge, no NETELLER customers suffered any financial losses
as a result. Similarly, to the best of the company’s knowledge, no Moneybookers’
customers suffered any financial losses as a result of the historic breach.
• The article did not contradict Optimal's account that the Neteller breach involved
only a marketing database with no financial information. Optimal indicates in the
article that the Moneybookers breach involved a production database with encrypted
passwords and card numbers, but that the forensic investigator believed the likelihood
of a successful transfer of the data to the attacker was low.
• The author was impressed with Optimal Payments' professionalism and openness. He
said the company was "refreshingly transparent", "responded quickly" and praised its
"exemplary reception of ethical disclosure". Optimal Payments reported the breaches
in 2009 & 2010 to the FSA (now the FCA) and were the subject of independent
forensic investigations from major accounting firms.

BE

The article alleges that the leaked databases contained 4.5m and 3.6m records from
Moneybookers (Skrill) and Neteller, respectively.
Optimal has commenced an investigation into the matter and the veracity of the
allegations (bought to the company by the journalist at Forbes), and has informed both
the Information Commissioner and the FCA.
Shares continue to trade at a discount to peer average (11.7x versus 13.5x FY2 EV/
EBITDA), despite strong growth and potential for earnings out performance, driven by
acquisition cost synergies, combined Skrill/ Neteller margin improvement and continued
strong growth against conservative market expectations.

11:53 am
BE

Moreover, we believe that virtually all VRX investors recognize that Mr. Pearson has been the chief architect of Valeant’s strategy since he became CEO in 2008, and they attribute much of the company’s success since then to him personally. Therefore, Valeant’s current issues aside, the prospect of not having Mr. Pearson at the helm is probably further eroding investor confidence, which probably explains today’s weakness.

BE

We see Mr. Pearson as a pioneer who has been able to successfully take advantage of the inefficiencies in his industry. We note that many other CEOs have since attempted to emulate his strategy. Moreover, we believe Valeant’s exceptional performance since Mr. Pearson became CEO has forced his peers in the Pharmaceutical industry to becomemore efficient. Unfortunately, Mr. Pearson’s blunt communication style, which ironically many investors appreciate, makes him vulnerable to attacks from the media and politicians, in our view. Some have even recently used his image as background for their attacks. Although we believe that the responsibility for Valeant’s affiliation with Philidor, whichhas caused this crisis of investor confidence, ultimately lies with Mr. Pearson, we do not believe that it is sufficientgrounds for his replacement. We argue that the current political climate made Valeant too vulnerable to Citron’sunfounded “fraud” allegations. Moreover, we argue that there may be few CEOs better equipped to bring Valeant out of the current crisis. Our recommendation for investors is unchanged: We continue to believe that the stock is undervalued relative to what we believe to be the underlying fundamentals. However, in the near term, headline risk remains high asValeant’s business practices are scrutinized. We believe that it will take some time to rebuild investor confidence; thus, investors should expect volatility. However, we would urge caution against calls to replace Mr. Pearson at this time.

PM

11:58 am
BE

What have we learned and read-across — Today’s aggressive change of outlook
and move to protect the balance sheet by Amec management highlights that a) the
depth and length of the downturn continues to be underappreciated by both OFS
companies and markets (Citi c15% below consensus sector EPS for 2016-2018); b)
customer behavior towards OFS is deteriorating, a trend that is reflected in
continued issues around variation orders and payment terms; c) levered names
continue to carry significantly higher risk, as deteriorating earnings push debt ratios
higher; and d) Amec’s diversification has failed to provide a buffer to returns as
outlook has also deteriorated across GPG, Renewables, Mining and Infrastructure.
Sector read-across is universally negative, and we reiterate our cautious view on
TEC, SDRL, TRE, PGS, WG (see today’s note), SUBC and PFC.

BE

What does it mean for the numbers – Our 2015-2020 EPS estimates are cut by
an average of 23%, as we incorporate lower headline expectations, negative
revenue effect on margins (e.g. more renewables, less O&G) and higher interest
cost. Our DCF based TP is cut to £6.3/sh, to reflect lower cash flows and LT growth
assumptions.
 Valuation; Downgrading to Neutral — We see limited upside for AMFW with
lowered estimates pointing to 8.7x EV/EBITDA in 2017E (in line with WG, Euro OFS
at 6-7x), and 2017E 1.5 P/B vs ROE of 13% (we assume $250m impairment for
GPG, etc). We also expect leverage concerns and lack of visibility to weigh on the
shares and downgrade AMFW to Neutral (from Buy).
 Balance sheet — We see the leverage ratio remaining c2.7-3.0x ND/EBITDA in the
short term, with limited FCF to pay down debt. A downside risk is that we estimate a
further 10% decline in revenue could see leverage breach covenant levels (3.25x).
Although no debt matures in the short term (acq. facility due in 1Q17), in the
absence of specific proposals for additional financing, we struggle to see a scenario
where the group retains its investment grade as the cash flow outlook deteriorates;
we assume 100bps higher interest cost going forward.

BE
